channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Nasdaq 100 Set for Record as Yields Fall on Powell: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street bulls drove stocks closer to all-time highs amid easing Middle East tensions and constructive comments from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell on the prospect of interest-rate cuts ahead. Bond yields and the dollar fell. Oil plunged.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Oil plunged by more than 7% as Iran’s response to US military strikes spared energy infrastructure, allaying investor concerns that the conflict would severely disrupt supplies from the Middle East. Alix Steel reports on Balance of Power.

item.title: Forever 21’s US Operator Wins Court Approval to Liquidate
item.description: The former operator of Forever 21’s US stores won court approval on a plan to partially repay vendors and other creditors that stand to incur big losses in the retailer’s bankruptcy.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Randles

media:content.media:description: A "Store Closing" sign displayed outside a Forever 21 store in New York, US, on Friday, March, 21, 2025. After filing for bankruptcy, Forever 21 plans on closing its last remaining stores in the US as the brand pursues a model that is similar to its online competitors.

item.title: Fed’s Powell Says SLR Reform Should Encourage Mediation
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell says potential changes to the enhanced supplementary leverage ratio (eSLR) should encourage banks to mediate in the Treasury markets. He speaks at a House Financial Services Committee hearing.

item.title: BOE’s Bailey Says Bond Sale Decision ‘More Interesting This Year’
item.description: Governor Andrew Bailey said the Bank of England’s looming annual decision on reducing its government bond portfolio will be “more interesting this year.” Bailey also told lawmakers at a hearing Tuesday that he sees “some slack opening up” in the nation’s economy. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Solana Treasury Firm Upexi Falls After Insider Sales Filing
item.description: Upexi Inc. tumbled as much as 63% following the filing of a registration statement to allow investors to sell common shares in the consumer brands company turned cryptocurrency accumulator.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Ogunrinde

item.title: BBVA’s Sabadell Bid in Doubt After Spain Delays Merger
item.description: BBVA SA‘s €14 billion ($16 billion) bid for rival Banco Sabadell SA suffered a major setback after the Spanish government said the two lenders wouldn’t be allowed to integrate their operations for several years.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Zuloaga, Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: The Banco de Sabadell SA office building in Barcelona. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: European Banks Face Profit Hit in S&P Trade War Stress Test
item.description: European banks would see their profits eroded if an escalation of trade tensions with the US leads to souring corporate loans, according to S&P Global Ratings.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Comfort

media:content.media:description: A Commerzbank AG bank branch in Frankfurt. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: German Car Parts Seller Autodoc Shelves IPO on Eve of Debut
item.description: German car parts retailer Autodoc SE postponed its Frankfurt initial public offering ahead of its expected market debut on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Pablo Mayo Cerqueiro, Swetha Gopinath

media:content.media:description: Workers load orders into a freight truck at the Autodoc automobile component warehouse in Berlin.

item.title: Chip Designer Ambarella Explores Potential Sale
item.description: Chip design company Ambarella Inc. is considering options including a potential sale, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Gould, Dinesh Nair

media:content.media:description: Ambarella Inc. headquarters in Santa Clara, California.

item.title: US Declares Power Emergency in Southeast on Heat Wave
item.description: The Trump administration has declared a power emergency in the US Southeast as a blistering heat wave strains grids across the country.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter, Josh Saul

media:content.media:description: Electrical transmission towers during a heatwave in Vallejo, California, US, on Sunday, Sept. 4, 2022. Blisteringly hot temperatures and a rash of wildfires are posing a twin threat to Californias power grid as a heat wave smothering the region peaks in the days ahead. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Ex-CFA Institute Executive Charged With Embezzling Millions
item.description: The CFA Institute’s former chief marketing officer was charged with embezzling nearly $5 million from the financial education group to fund a lavish lifestyle that included club memberships, travel and the purchase of a $150,000 engagement ring.
item.dc:creator: Anika Arora Seth

item.title: Powell Says Fed Doesn’t Need to Rush to Cut Rates
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell says if inflation is contained the central bank will cut rates sooner rather than later during testimony before the US House Financial Services Committee.

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 6/24/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Emerging-Market Currencies See Fresh Lift on Powell’s Remarks
item.description: Emerging-market assets touched a session high as traders parsed through Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s remarks to lawmakers for signals on the direction of US monetary policy.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Simauchi, Raphael Almeida

item.title: Treasuries Gain on Drop in Consumer Confidence, Powell Comments
item.description: Treasuries advanced on a surprisingly weak consumer-confidence report and as Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said “many paths are possible” for monetary policy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Carter Johnson, James Hirai

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians outside the New York Stock Exchange. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s Wealth Fund Pulls Plug on $1 Billion Private Equity Sale
item.description: China’s sovereign wealth fund has pulled its planned sale of $1 billion in US fund stakes tied to some of the biggest names in private equity.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Dawn Lim, Dingmin Zhang, Preeti Singh

item.title: French Government Under Pressure as Pension Talks Stumble
item.description: Negotiations over France’s contentious retirement reform ended in deadlock late Monday, raising pressure on the government as some opposition parties called for a no-confidence vote.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

item.title: Trump Eases Pressure on Iran by Saying China Can Buy Its Oil
item.description: President Donald Trump said China can continue to purchase oil from Iran, abruptly easing the “maximum pressure” the US had been applying to the Middle Eastern country’s economic lifeblood.
item.dc:creator: Grant Smith

media:content.media:description: A refinery on the South Pars Gas-Condensate field in Asalouyeh Seaport in Iran.

item.title: Oil Drops as Trump Cheers Slide with Iran-Israel Truce Back On
item.description: Oil plunged for a second straight day as US President Donald Trump signalled he wants to keep oil flowing out of Iran after brokering a fragile ceasefire between Tehran and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Mia Gindis

media:content.media:description: Oil storage tanks at the Sunoco LP Terminal in Crockett, California, US, on Friday, Jan. 3, 2025. Oil began 2025 by rising to the highest level since November, boosted by a report of shrinking crude stockpiles in the US and bullish technical indicators.

item.title: Tina Fordham: Aftermath of Iran Regime Change
item.description: Tina Fordham, Fordham Global Foresight Founder & Geopolitical Strategist, talks about what happens next if the current government in Iran should fall. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Uranium Miner’s Russian Routes Unnerve Potential Bond Investors
item.description: Money managers are raising red flags about a planned $300 million bond sale by one of the world’s largest uranium miners, citing the company’s reliance on Russian transport routes.
item.dc:creator: Edward Clark

media:content.media:description: Cylinders of uranium from a Russian cargo ship.

item.title: Colombia Bond Investors Are Ready to Ride Out Gustavo Petro's Final Year in Office
item.description: Investors in Colombia’s dollar bonds are digging in for the final stretch of Gustavo Petro’s presidency, hoping that next year’s election will bring relief after years of fiscal and political missteps.
item.dc:creator: Maria Elena Vizcaino, Nicolle Yapur

media:content.media:description: Gustavo Petro, Colombia's president, center, speaks during an event at La Alpujarra Administrative Center in Medellin, Colombia, on Saturday, June 21, 2025. Petro wants to hold a vote on creating an assembly to change the constitution, aiming to put the question to voters on the day of the 2026 elections.

item.title: US Consumer Confidence Declines on Economic Concerns
item.description: US consumer confidence unexpectedly declined in June on concerns about prospects for the economy. The Conference Board’s gauge of confidence decreased 5.4 points to 93, below all estimates in a Bloomberg survey of economists. Mike McKee reports on “Bloomberg Open Interest.”

item.title: Mideast Oil Flows Set to Rebound After Diving Monday
item.description: The flow of oil out of the Persian Gulf plunged on Monday — a sign that some owners have have been wary of the security situation — but are on course to recover sharply.
item.dc:creator: Prejula Prem

item.title: Cheniere Will Invest $2.9 Billion to Expand Texas Natural Gas Export Plant
item.description: Liquefied natural gas exporter Cheniere Energy Inc. plans to spend $2.9 billion on the next expansion trains at its Texas facility in Corpus Christi.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Liao

media:content.media:description: The Cheniere Liquefaction facility (CCL) Stage 3 project under construction in Corpus Christi, Texas, US, on Monday, Dec. 4, 2023. Cheniere's Corpus Christi Stage 3 expansion is part of the third and biggest wave of new liquefied natural gas supply to enter the global market.

item.title: Morgan Stanley's Shalett on Stocks: 'Hold on Loosely'
item.description: "Hold on loosely and be open to diversification," Morgan Stanley Wealth CIO Lisa Shalett advises while discussing her investment strategy on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: ECB’s Lane Says Disinflation Process Is ‘Largely Completed’
item.description: European Central Bank Chief Economist Philip Lane said the process of bringing inflation back to 2% is almost over, despite some pockets of elevated price pressures remaining.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: Chief economist of the ECB Philip Lane

item.title: EQB Says CEO Andrew Moor Has Died, CRO Named Interim Leader
item.description: EQB Inc. Chief Executive Officer Andrew Moor died unexpectedly at the age of 65 over the weekend and Marlene Lenarduzzi has been named interim leader.
item.dc:creator: Christine Dobby

media:content.media:description: EQ Bank CEO Andrew Moor at Bloomberg's Toronto bureau on April 5, 2024

item.title: Hammack Says Fed May Hold Rates Steady for Some Time
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland President Beth Hammack said policy may stay on hold “for quite some time before the committee initiates very modest cuts to return policy to a neutral setting.” Hammack also said that despite recent progress, the Fed still has “some distance to go” before it reaches its inflation target. She spoke Tuesday during a conference in London.

item.title: Battery CEO Says US Senate’s Clean Energy Bill Is ‘Workable’
item.description: Battery storage company Fluence Energy Inc. said it can work with US Senate Republicans’ latest version of President Donald Trump’s fiscal package, which would preserve tax credits for the industry while gutting incentives for wind and solar power.
item.dc:creator: Tope Alake

media:content.media:description: Julian Nebreda, president and chief executive officer of Fluence Energy Inc., during the 2023 CERAWeek by S&P Global conference in Houston, Texas, US, on Thursday, March 9, 2023. The global energy industry is facing a welter of uncertainty and change -- driven by the effects of the global pandemic; shifting geopolitics and a war launched by one of the world's major energy powers; high energy prices; supply chain and infrastructure constraints; and economic instability.
